tables.content: Guiding principle and associated research Definition A comprehensive set of objectives and activities such as audience identification, issue analysis, goal definition, and the selection of tactics and evaluation criteria. Construct Integrated communications strategy Type Lead

Key findings High adherence rate (92%) and potential for exercise routine personalization based on user feedback. Correlation between AI engagement and greater weight loss outcomes. Mixed effectiveness in improving physical activity and diet. (continued) Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted health content, cyclical conversations, repetition, company-specific social context. Lead Targeted demographic and health content, cyclical conversations, with repetition through regular weigh-ins. Lead Targeted demographic and health messages, cyclical feedback loop, and repetition. Lead Content creation Content creation methods not specified. Content included exercise instructions and reminders sent daily. The use of a chatbot for delivery suggests that instructions were possibly text-based. Content creation methods not specified. Content included personalized conversations and educational lessons. Content creation methods not specified. Content included daily contact and personalization. Utilizing a conversational agent to deliver content tailored to promote health behavior changes in physical activity and fruit and vegetable consumption. AI details AI-assisted program for exercise and motivational messaging. Includes exercise instructions, motivation, interaction, and adherence monitoring AI-powered coaching for personalized health behavior change Early-stage chatbot with scripted dialogues for health communication AI interface App and chatbot App Chatbot Health focus Musculoskeletal symptoms management Weight management Physical activity and diet Behavioral theory Not explicitly mentioned, but implies the use of behavior change principles Implies reliance on engagement metrics and their association with weight loss outcomes Implied use of the transtheoretical model, motivational interviewing, and social cognitive theory Sample and characteristics 94 employees aged 20- 64, with own cellphones for app installation, who understood and agreed to study publication. 538 adults aged 65þ, kg/m 2 BMI �25 , enrolled in diabetes prevention programs for at least 3 months, with weight loss as a goal. Demographics: mean age of 67.47 years, 61% female, 16% nonwhite, and mean BMI 32.61 kg/m 2 . 122 (113 completed) participants, 18 and older, with internet access, able to walk unaided, understood English, in early stages of adopting physical activity and diet guidelines. Ages 21-69, 61% female, majority white (52%) and Asian (33%), single, some college education. Study and study type Anan et al., 2021 2-armed, randomised, controlled, unblinded trial Auster-Gussman et al., 2022 Longitudinal, observational study Bickmore et al., 2013 4-arm randomised controlled trial

Key findings Increased readiness to quit, though limitations in understanding human inputs were noted. High retention and cessation rates due to adaptive personalization. Significant reduction in mood episodes, despite non-randomized group allocation and engagement challenges. Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted demographic and health content, cyclical daily feedback, repetition. Lead Targeted health messaging enhanced by app feedback mechanisms to encourage user engagement. Lead Factual content with cyclical conversations and repetition. Lag Content creation The core of the chatbot's content was rooted in motivational interviewing. Emphasizing empathy, reflective listening, and the empowerment of individuals to make their own choices. Content included scripted questions and engagement in dialogue; reflective responses; empathy and support; and iterative feedback for improvement. Content included 500 motivational messages developed from theory-driven, expert-written sources and peer- written messages. Content creation methods not specified. Content included mood prediction reports; health metric score feedback; behavioral guidance; and an alert system. AI details Uses NLP and GPT-2 XL for generative reflections and motivational interviewing Hybrid ML algorithm for dynamic message personalization based on user feedback Predictive algorithms from wearable tracker data for mood episode prediction Health focus AI interface Smoking cessation Chatbot Smoking cessation Chatbot Mood disorder App prevention Behavioral theory Indicated to be based in motivational interviewing Use of motivational messages implies underlying behavioral change theories Implied development of behavioral guidance and interventions informed by behavioral science principles Sample and characteristics 349 participants, minimum age 18, fluent in English, current or recent smokers, with a high approval rate on prior studies. Balanced gender sample, mean age 30, lighter smokers with a mean of 10.8 cigarettes daily. 731 English-speaking current smokers older than 18 years. Demographics: 13% Black, 73% women, and an age range from younger than 25 to older than 54 years. 43 patients with major mood disorder, aged 18-75, after data qualification. Mixed gender, majority diagnosed with bipolar disorder type I in the CRM group. Age range 22.97 to 35.30 years. Study and study type Brown et al., 2023 Single-arm study Chen et al., 2021 Prospective cohort study Cho et al., 2020 Prospective case- control study

Key findings Association among app usage frequency, duration, and weight loss. Guiding construct (lead or lag) Target demographic and health specific content. Lead Integrated targeted health content combined with cyclical conversations and repetition through AI-driven coaching, regular weigh-ins, and feedback loops. Content creation Content creation methods not specified. It implies the utilization of AI to analyze user data and generate feedback, but it does not elaborate on the algorithms, data models, or health theories used to shape this process. Personalized AI-driven feedback. The app's central feature is the chatbot that delivers personalized feedback to users based on their input data regarding diet, sleep, weight, and physical activities at the gym. Content creation methods not specified. Content included interactive communication and personalized feedback. Focusing on the practical application of AI to facilitate engagement, learning, and efficacy in teaching effective parenting skills, particularly the use of positive attention and praise. AI details AI chatbot analyzes user inputs for personalized feedback AI chatbot delivering parenting intervention AI interface App and chatbot Chatbot Health focus Weight management Parenting skills enhancement Behavioral theory Not explicitly stated; implies behavioral science principles linked to content creation Principles from the Incredible Years parenting program Sample and characteristics 26,589 gym members aged 20-80 who used the app at least twice. Predominantly male (63.8%); average age 38.9. 170 parents in Argentina, with at least 1 child aged 2- 11 years. Mostly female (95.1%), with university/ undergraduate education (73%), married (69.7%), and employed (83.1%). Study and study type Eguchi et al., 2023 Longitudinal regression analysis Entenberg et al., 2023 Randomised controlled trial

Key findings Improvements in physical activity, weight loss, and HbA1c levels noted. CDC qualifiers maintained greater weight loss; challenges in reaching non- qualifiers noted. (continued) Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted health content with cyclical conversations and repetition through regular coaching interactions. Lead and lag Targeted demographic and health content specificity incorporating cyclical conversations. Lead and lag Content creation The app delivers context-aware, just- in-time health coaching tailored to the individual's lifestyle, which suggests an underlying reliance on principles of personalized communication and behavioral science, including personalized health recommendations. Real-time feedback and encouragement; activity and weight tracking; integration with digital body weight scale and behavioral change goals. The content is derived from the CDC PreventT2 curriculum, which is designed to help individuals at risk for type 2 diabetes make achievable and sustainable lifestyle changes, including nutritional guidance; physical activity advice; weight management strategies; behavioral change support; and health monitoring and encouragement. AI details ML for personalized health coaching based on lifestyle data AI coaching for personalized support AI interface Chatbot App Health focus Diabetes and weight management Diabetes and weight management Behavioral theory Just-in-time adaptive intervention Implied: cognitive behavioral therapy and positive psychology Sample and characteristics 47 participants with prediabetes, BMI 24-40 kg/m 2 (22-40 kg/ m 2 for Asians), English-speaking, owning a smartphone. Predominantly female (60%), white (71%), middle-aged with a mean of 55 years, obese (91% with BMI �30 kg/ m 2 ), with a median baseline HbA1c of 6.0%. 3,933 members older than 18, initial BMI kg/m 2 �25 , diagnosed with prediabetes or at high risk for T2D, enrolled through health insurance plans or employers. Demographics are not fully detailed but indicate a majority of older adults, significantly female and white. Study and study type Everett et al., 2018 Single-arm, prospective observational study Graham et al., 2022 Retrospective, longitudinal study

Key findings Significant increase in daily steps among participants. Enhanced user engagement and retention through predictive modeling and personalized content. Reduction in depressive symptoms among users engaging with the AI. (continued) Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted health messaging including cyclical conversations and repetition of specific tools and techniques for emotional and stress management within the app. Lead and lag Targeted health messaging, including cyclical conversations and repetition. Lead and lag Targeted health messaging with a cyclical conversations, emphasizing repetition of self- monitoring behaviors for behavior modification. Lead and lag Content creation Content creation methods not specified. Content included voice- assisted AI coaching (MyCoach) and autonomous AI coaching delivered by text message (SmartText). Culturally tailored animated videos, quizzes, and expert videos. Content creation methods not specified. Indicates that the content was created based on a combination of AI technology and evidence-based psychological practices, aimed at delivering personalized mental health support, including AI-enabled personalized AI details Voice-assisted AI coaching via smart speaker and text messaging for personalized coaching AI-based predictive models for user engagement, content personalization, and learning journeys AI identifies emotional state for empathetic responses and personalized support AI interface AI coaching App Chatbot Health focus Physical activity for cancer survivors General health awareness Maternal mental health Behavioral theory Recommendation system (AI agent) with supervised and unsupervised goal models Implied: behavior change theories to enhance digital health interventions CBT, DBT, ACT, mindfulness practices, and motivational interviewing (embedded within AI responses) Sample and characteristics 39 Maryland adults with a history of certain cancers, overweight or obese, completed cancer treatment at least 3 months prior, 91% female, 36% Black; mean age 62.1 years; mean BMI 32.9 kg/ m 2 ; 85.7% breast cancer survivors. Reached >10 million users of the Saathealth mobile app, focusing on resource-limited communities in India. Detailed engagement metrics provided. 51 female users of the Wysa app who self- reported a maternal event, completed 2 PHQ-9 assessments, and had engagement data available. Predominantly located in North America, with some in Europe. 50% single, 10% married. Study and study type Hassoon et al., 2021 Single-center, 3- arm randomised controlled trial Hazra-Ganju et al., 2023 Case study Inkster et al., 2023 Mixed-method real-world data study

Key findings The chatbot encouraged 58% of participants to be more active in improving their condition. Higher engagement correlated with significant weight loss at both 8 and 24 weeks. ML identified key predictors of engagement and health outcomes, including psychological constructs: motivation and self-esteem. (continued) Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted health messaging, fostering cyclical conversations and repetitive engagement with the mobile app through daily feedback and assignments. Lead and lag Targeted health and demographic messaging, identifiable characters, and social constructs, with cyclical conversations, repetition, and transmedia storytelling techniques. Lead and lag Content creation interaction; guided conversations and self-help tools; emotional support and guidance; and behavioral and cognitive exercises. Content creation methods not specified. Content included tailored health recommendations for SCD self-care. Content creation methods not specified. Content included leveraged elements of digital CBT principles, including personalized feedback, and interactive assignments. The personalized feedback was tailored to individual participants, possibly developed through the analysis of user input data (such as meal logs, activity AI details AI chatbot for personalized health coaching and SCD management advice ML used to analyze digital phenotypes for predicting engagement and health outcomes Health focus AI interface SCD awareness Chatbot Weight management App Behavioral theory Implied: principles of health coaching and patient empowerment Implied: behavior change theories emphasizing self- monitoring, goal setting, feedback, reinforcement Sample and characteristics 19 participants diagnosed with SCD, at least 16 years old, French-speaking, owning a smartphone. 17 completed the evaluation. Patients aged between 19 and 59 years, both male and female. 45 female participants aged 18-39 years, BMI 25-40 kg/m 2 , eligible for smartphone use, and high scores on the Situational Motivation Scale. Analysis performed on 37 participants after exclusions. Study and study type Issom et al., 2020 Preliminary feasibility study Kim et al., 2021 Retrospective observational study

Key findings High adherence and significant weight loss in users with high engagement. Effective in personalizing health communication and improving user engagement. (continued) Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted demographic and health content. Lead Targeted health messaging was designed for cyclical interaction and repetition as part of a broader health campaign, including an omni channel distribution approach. Lead and lag Content creation levels, and progress toward goals) by the mobile app's underlying AI and ML algorithms. Content creation methods not specified. Content included personalized coaching; customized feedback; self- monitoring; dietary and exercise logs; weight tracking; engagement through text messaging; interactive messaging; notifications and reminders; educational content and interactive tools. Content creation methods not specified. Content included educational content; behavioral experiments with social support; and gamification and incentives. AI details ML analysis of user data for engagement prediction and behavior analysis NLP and ML for personalized communications and advice Health focus AI interface Weight management App Asthma Chatbot management Behavioral theory Implied that CBT principles applied through Noom Behavior change techniques, experiential learning theory Sample and characteristics 13,140 adults with BMI kg/m 2 �25 enrolled in Noom's coaching program. Predominantly female (92.03%), average age 43.9 years. 49 children aged 10- 15 years with asthma and access to a smartphone, German-speaking. Average age, 12; 67% male, 33% female. Study and study type Kim et al., 2022 Randomised controlled trial Kowatsch et al., 2021 Multisite single- arm feasibility study

Key findings Improved mental health outcomes and significant user engagement reported. High grammatical accuracy and appropriate content difficulty level, with some demographic limitations. Wide reach and high engagement, though faced with challenges in handling unanticipated questions and maintaining interaction rates. (continued) Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted health messaging that included a feedback loop providing repetition and cyclic conversations. Lead and lag Targeted health messaging, using a feedback loop for self- management, and educational messages on a cyclical basis. Lead and lag Targeted health messages with a focus on maintaining engagement through daily repetition. Lead and lag Content creation Content creation methods not specified. Content included AI- based conversational support. Content creation methods not specified. Content included AI- generated patient educational materials. Content creation methods not specified. Content included evidence-based information on alcohol use. AI details Conversational agent supporting mental health, analyzing conversational data for user needs Conversational AI for generating patient educational materials Digital conversational agent for public education AI interface App ChatGPT Chatbot Health focus Chronic pain management Public health education Alcohol use education Behavioral theory Not explicitly linked but based on principles of CBT, behavioral reinforcement, mindfulness Not explicitly mentioned Not explicitly mentioned Sample and characteristics 2,194 users reporting chronic pain and engaged with an unspecified app. Details on demographics are not specified. NA: Study based on AI- generated patient education materials on public health issues in India. No direct human subjects involved. 1,532 users interested in alcohol-related topics on the Pan American Health Organization website out of 188,000 visitors. Mostly from Latin America and the Caribbean, higher proportion of female users, main age range 35- 44 years. Study and study type Meheli et al., 2022 Observational, cross-sectional study Mondal et al., 2023 Analysis of digital conversational agent deployment and engagement metrics Monteiro et al., 2023 Non-randomised controlled trial

Key findings Improved outcomes when AI combined with human messages, but AI alone showed limitations in sustaining behavior changes. Improvement in LBP- related disability, self-efficacy, and satisfaction with the app. Increased influence ratings among smokers; no significant difference in cessation rates observed. (continued) Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted health messaging that included a feedback loop providing repetition and cyclic conversations. Lead and lag Targeted health messaging, using a feedback loop for self- management, and educational messages on a cyclical basis. Lead and lag Targeted health messages with a focus on maintaining engagement through daily repetition. Lead and lag Content creation Content creation methods not specified. Content included AI- based text messages, human-delivered video messages. Content creation methods not specified. Content included tailored physical activity recommendations, including personalized physical activity recommendations; strength and flexibility exercises; and educational messages. Content creation methods not specified. Content included tailored motivational messaging for smoking cessation, including peer stories. Health focus AI interface AI details Dietary management App and chatbot AI for dietary advice based on meal photos and user data LBP management App Uses case-based reasoning for AI approach Smoking cessation Recommender system Hybrid ML system for tailoring motivational messaging Behavioral theory Implied application of principles from several behavior change theories References SCT in the development of PERSPeCT Implied SCT, transtheoretical model, theory of reasoned action Sample and characteristics 102 users of a smartphone diet management app. Demographics not specified. 461 participants with LBP, aged 18 or older, with access to email, computer, and smartphone. Mixed adult population with nonspecific LBP. 120 current smokers aged 18 or older, English-speaking, with Internet access. Majority female (64.2%), aged 45 or older (38.3%), college graduates (58.8%), and white (91.7%). Study and study type Okaniwa & Yoshida, 2022 Randomised controlled trial Rughani et al., 2023 Randomised controlled trial Sadasivam et al., 2016 Randomised controlled trial

Key findings AI-generated messages rated similarly to human ones, though some inaccuracies were noted. Increased engagement and significant improvements in symptoms of anxiety and depression. Tess facilitated personalized support, demonstrating improved capability through continuous learning from user interactions. (continued) Guiding construct (lead or lag) Targeted health messaging with social constructs through educational setting. Targeted health messaging, engaging cyclical conversations. Lead and lag Targeted health messaging, cyclical conversations, and repetition Lead and lag Content creation GPT-2 generated health messages. Content creation methods not specified. Content included AI-led conversations; implied psychological based interventions; pandemic-specific support; educational content; and self- assessment tools. Content included messaging with adolescent patients via SMS text messaging and Facebook Messenger. The chatbot delivered customized integrative support, psychoeducation, and interventions through brief conversations tailored to each participant's specific needs. Predominantly female (74.4%); mean age, 20 years; recruited from a large Midwestern university. 4,541 users evaluated for engagement; 2,061 for depression and 2,995 for anxiety efficacy assessments. Engagement with an app during the study period, with details on demographics adhering to privacy policies. 23 youth with obesity symptoms, BMI �95% for age and sex, and �1 comorbid condition, enrolled in a multidisciplinary weight management program.
